ELECTRICAL CLUB HOLDS
ANNUAL SMOKER
Electrical Display Planned for June
Week

The annual smoker of the Electrical Club was held in Room 101
M. E., Friday, December 14. The
program for the evening included
talks by members of the faculty
of the engineering college and a
musical program rendered by the
members of the club. The faculty
was represented by Dr. Whitehead, Dr. Lee, Dr. Kouwenhouven
and Mr. Lampe. The outstanding
feature of the musical end of the
program was a "harp" solo rendered by Mr. C. R. Stouch on his
newly perfected "electrical harp."
Other selections were given by a
quartet composed of Messrs.
Black, Crider, Stouch and White.
During the evening the possibility of devoting an evening to
"stunts" next spring was discussed. The plan for such an evening would include a display of
the electrical apparatus owned by
the University. It was suggested
that such a display might be
worked in connection with June
week.
After the adjournment of the
smoker at 7:45 the members of
the club attended a meeting of the
American Institute of Electrical
Engineers at the Engineers Club.

BALTIMORE, MD., DECEMBER 21, 1923

NEW LIFE
After a period of comparative inactivity the Publicity Board has
resumed functioning on a large scale. According to reports issuing
from the headquarters of that organization, news concerning Hopkins
non-athletic and athletic, is being broadcasted from coast to coast
and the name "Johns Hopkins" is being brought before the eyes of
readers throughout the United States.
In the strictly competitive world of today, no institution or organization can subsist without advertisement. Johns Hopkins is
known mostly in this country as a Medical School; the information
that an undergraduate body and undergraduate activities exist has
been spread very slowly.
The Publicity Board has it in its power to make the United
States acquainted with Hopkins. Its recent progressive steps are to
be commended and the responsible individuals to be congratulated.

SHAFTESBURY ADDRESSES
FIELD CLUB
Archibald D. Shaftesbury delivered a lantern slide address on the
subject of bees at the last meeting of the Field Club. Mr. Shaftesbury, who for some years has
made a detailed study of this insect, gave a delightful picture of
the bee's habits and life history.
He placed special emphasis on the
importance of the bee in the pollination of flowers and fruits. The
manufacture of honey is but a
small part of the bee's contribution
to nature; pollination is by far its
greatest accomplishment.
Preliminary to the lecture, a
business meeting was held in
which officers for the club were
chosen. Mr. Shaftesbury was
elected president and Mr. Archibald N. McPherson secretary.

As regular as the hanging of the stocking on the hearth is the
News-Letter's annual request that undergraduates "Talk Hopkins"
during the holidays. Assuming the risk of appearing trite and unoriginal, we wish to again urge that Hopkins men leaving Baltimore
for other points retain thoughts of the University and tell others,
especially preparatory school men, the attractions of Homewood.
And—if at any time one should run short of data—dwell on the Maryland game.
If we thought we'd get a gymnasium, a Student Activities Building
or anything like that, we'd hang up our stocking, too.

THE CAMPUS BEAUTIFUL
Johns Hopkins may not have had the best football team in the
country and may not possess the best newspaper or the most famous
Musical Clubs. We have, however, a campus that is surpassed in
beauty by few—very few—in the United States. Visitors to Homewood have often marvelled at the distinctiveness and attractiveness
of the buildings and the grounds. And now, as if to silence all dispute, University authorities are making further improvements which
promise to make the picturesqueness and general grace of Hopkins
campus almost unrivalled.
We fear that there are numerous undergraduates who do not
appreciate their "campus beautiful."

ELECTRICAL CLUB HOLDS
ANNUAL SMOKER
Electrical Display Planned for June
Week

The annual smoker of the Electrical Club was held in Room 101
M. E., Friday, December 14. The
program for the evening included
talks by members of the faculty
of the engineering college and a
musical program rendered by the
members of the club. The faculty
was represented by Dr. Whitehead, Dr. Lee, Dr. Kouwenhouven
and Mr. Lampe. The outstanding
feature of the musical end of the
program was a "harp" solo rendered by Mr. C. R. Stouch on his
newly perfected "electrical harp."
Other selections were given by a
quartet composed of Messrs.
Black, Crider, Stouch and White.
During the evening the possibility of devoting an evening to
"stunts" next spring was discussed. The plan for such an evening would include a display of
the electrical apparatus owned by
the University. It was suggested
that such a display might be
worked in connection with June
week.
After the adjournment of the
smoker at 7:45 the members of
the club attended a meeting of the
American Institute of Electrical
Engineers at the Engineers Club.

BALTIMORE, MD., DECEMBER 21, 1923

NEW LIFE
After a period of comparative inactivity the Publicity Board has
resumed functioning on a large scale. According to reports issuing
from the headquarters of that organization, news concerning Hopkins
non-athletic and athletic, is being broadcasted from coast to coast
and the name "Johns Hopkins" is being brought before the eyes of
readers throughout the United States.
In the strictly competitive world of today, no institution or organization can subsist without advertisement. Johns Hopkins is
known mostly in this country as a Medical School; the information
that an undergraduate body and undergraduate activities exist has
been spread very slowly.
The Publicity Board has it in its power to make the United
States acquainted with Hopkins. Its recent progressive steps are to
be commended and the responsible individuals to be congratulated.

SHAFTESBURY ADDRESSES
FIELD CLUB
Archibald D. Shaftesbury delivered a lantern slide address on the
subject of bees at the last meeting of the Field Club. Mr. Shaftesbury, who for some years has
made a detailed study of this insect, gave a delightful picture of
the bee's habits and life history.
He placed special emphasis on the
importance of the bee in the pollination of flowers and fruits. The
manufacture of honey is but a
small part of the bee's contribution
to nature; pollination is by far its

As regular as the hanging of the stocking on the hearth is the
News-Letter's annual request that undergraduates "Talk Hopkins"
during the holidays. Assuming the risk of appearing trite and unoriginal, we wish to again urge that Hopkins men leaving Baltimore
for other points retain thoughts of the University and tell others,
especially preparatory school men, the attractions of Homewood.
And—if at any time one should run short of data—dwell on the Maryland game.
If we thought we'd get a gymnasium, a Student Activities Building
or anything like that, we'd hang up our stocking, too.

THE CAMPUS BEAUTIFUL
Johns Hopkins may not have had the best football team in the
country and may not possess the best newspaper or the most famous
Musical Clubs. We have, however, a campus that is surpassed in
beauty by few—very few—in the United States. Visitors to Homewood have often marvelled at the distinctiveness and attractiveness
of the buildings and the grounds. And now, as if to silence all dispute, University authorities are making further improvements which
promise to make the picturesqueness and general grace of Hopkins
campus almost unrivalled.
We fear that there are numerous undergraduates who do not
appreciate their "campus beautiful."
